content:
Your consciousness is big enough for both of them as that is likely its current state, haha. It is functionally similar however to running Windows 11 and *also* running Windows 10. It is actually physically analogous as well, as your self-image starts at a very young age when you learn the word "Me", conceptualize it as yourself, and then start building a snowball of beliefs about it over your life. 

What is physically happening is you have one set of psychological reactions that respond to immediately what you perceive in the environment around you, and another set of psychological reactions that interpret what you are perceiving through the lens of belief and react to that as well. 

This sounds logical, but what is not understood until after self-realization is that the first set of psychological reactions that respond to what you perceive in the environment *includes* your own thoughts already. Your thoughts are actually part of the present environment and exist *only* right now as your perceive them. We don't typically believe this however, and because we think thoughts encompass duration (past and future) and have a sense of volume (like a library or hard drive) we respond to our imagination twice.

> What? How can you say that there is "previous moments of present experience" and also "there is nothing from the past and future we can imagine or think of"*

*What? How can you say that there is "previous moments of seeing" and also "there is nothing from the past and future we can see"*

The root is because fundamental identity without thought or belief is "exactly what I currently experience"

Self-image is imagination, and that imagination is our memory, which is really just previous moments of present experience being recalled and reconfigured. 

It's not that memory or imagination is a problem, but that all memory and imagination needs to be recognized not as past experience, but as "what I can presently think/imagine" and it's not something of the past or another time period. There is nothing from the past or future we can imagine or think of.
